thread.title: Ranking the 10 best California-born NASCAR drivers
thread.title_full: Ranking the 10 best California-born NASCAR drivers

title: Ranking the 10 best California-born NASCAR drivers
text:
Mar 22, 2017 at 4:51p ET 0Shares Getty Images Jerry Markland 
As NASCAR finishes up its West Coast trip with Sunday’s Monster Energy Series race at Auto Club Speedway, it’s the perfect time to take a look at some of the best drivers from the Golden State. 
With a number of successful drivers on this list, take a look as we rank the top-10 best that hail from California. Nigel Kinrade/LAT Photo USA 10 AJ Allmendinger 
The ‘Dinger scored his first and only Premier Series victory at Watkins Glen in 2014. Along with the win, the driver of the No. 47 JTG Daugherty Racing Chevy has also earned 10 top fives and 48 top-10 finishes in 303 total races. 9 Robby Gordon 
With three victories, 16 top fives and 39 top-10 results in 396 races at NASCAR’s highest level, Gordon ranks just ahead of Allmendinger. Getty Images Getty Images 8 Kyle Larson 
The Chip Ganassi Racing driver earned his first career Monster Energy Series victory at Michigan International Speedway in August 2016. He’s currently on a streak of five consecutive runner-up finishes dating back to the 2016 season finale at Homestead. 
If Larson continues on the road he's on, he'll move up on this list in no time. The Enthusiast Network The Enthusiast Network 7 Dan Gurney 
Although Gurney never participated in a full-time Premier Series season, he earned five victories, eight top fives and 10 top-10 finishes in just 16 races over 10 years. 6 Dick Rathman 
From 1951 through 1955, Rathman participated in 129 Premier Series events, scoring 13 wins, 69 top fives and 79 top-10 finishes. Focus on Sport Focus on Sport/Getty Images 5 Ernie Irvan 
Irvan was one of NASCAR’s biggest names in the early to mid-90s, scoring 15 wins in 313 races in the span of his 13-year Cup career, including the 1991 Daytona 500. 
Even more remarkable is how he was able to comeback from a serious head injury following a scary crash at Michigan in 1994 to be named one of NASCAR’s 50 Greatest Drivers in 1998. Getty Images Maddie Meyer 4 Ron Hornaday, Jr. 
Racing primary in the Camping World Truck Series throughout his career, Hornaday earned four championships, 51 wins, 158 top fives and 234 top-10 finishes in 360 races entered. 
He also dabbled in the XFINITY Series along the way, earning four wins in 184 total races over the course of 15 years. 
Hornaday’s final full-time Truck season was in 2013. © Matthew T. Thacker/LAT Photo USA Matthew T. Thacker 3 Kevin Harvick 
Following Dale Earnhardt’s death in 2001, Harvick took over the No. 3 Richard Childress Racing Chevy and scored his first career Cup win at Atlanta in just his third race. 
Since then, the Bakersfield native has earned one championship (2014), 35 total wins, 154 top fives and 286 top 10s. Getty Images Jonathan Moore 2 Jeff Gordon 
The four-time Cup champion and current FOX NASCAR analyst claims two different hometowns – Vallejo, California and Pittsboro, Indiana. 
After starting in quarter-midgets in California, Gordon moved to the Hoosier State to move his way up the open-wheel sprint car ranks. 
Since his first full-time Premier Series season in 1993, Gordon racked up an incredible 93 career wins, 325 top fives, 477 top-10 finishes and 81 poles. 
He retired from full-time competition in 2015, earning his final victory at Martinsville that fall. 
Gordon falls a close second to the driver of the car he co-owns. Getty Images Chris Trotman 1 Jimmie Johnson 
After Johnson tied Richard Petty and Dale Earnhardt with a remarkable seven Premier Series championship, he solidified his case for being at the top of this list. 
Johnson earned his first career Cup victory in his home state after winning at Auto Club Speedway in 2002. 
Since then, he and longtime crew chief Chad Knaus have earned 80 victories, 218 top fives and 331 top-10 finishes. 
If Johnson can score a record eighth championship before it's all said and done, the debate of whether or not he's NASCAR's G.O.A.T. will officially be laid to rest.
